title: Coke Cuts Costs, Raises Prices to Offset Sluggish Soda Sales
text:
Coke Cuts Costs, Raises Prices to Offset Sluggish Soda Sales By Amelia Martyn-Hemphill | 07/22/15 - 01:39 PM EDT 
NEW YORK ( TheStreet ) -- Coca-Cola ( KO - Get Report ) posted second-quarter earnings on Wednesday that beat estimates as it cut expenses and raised prices to counter sluggish sales as consumers drink less soda. 
Coke is focusing on its non-carbonated beverages and energy drink lines to win back more health-conscious customers. 
The company reported earnings of 63 cents share, down from last year's 64 cents a share and ahead of analysts' average estimate of 60 cents. Revenue fell 3% for the quarter, but still beat estimates. 
In Europe and the U.S., the beverage maker has been rolling out smaller soda cans for higher prices and has benefited from an increased marketing budget and the "share a Coke" campaign. The company has also teamed up with JetBlue ( JBLU ) to share travel rewards with customers.

Coke's other products include drinks such as PowerAde, Fanta, Sprite and Dasani. Around 41% of sales came from international markets, with worldwide sales volume up 2& last quarter. Coke took a battering from the strong U.S. dollar which has risen over 8% in 2015. 
"While there is more work to do, we remain confident that we have the right plans in place and are committed to leveraging our superior brand portfolio together with our unparalleled global distribution system to continue creating long-term shareowner value," CEO Muhtar Kent said in a statement. 
The Atlanta-based company is aiming to save around $3 billion by 2019 through cost-cutting initiatives and plans to divest around 50% of its U.S. distribution by 2017. 
Last month, Coke bought a 16.7% stake in Monster Beverage to gain access to Monster's non-energy portfolio, including natural soda and iced-tea lines.
